reviewText:
How do you call something robbing itself apart while the nejadná only the copying of intellectual ideas or gaming machine. This is a copy of the game almost 1: 1, which is not trying to sell as a completely new title! It is therefore self-plagiarism. And although we have a similar feats in the world of games and unfortunately almost wont Shooting from different titles in the RTS, it is really new. Welcome to zero innovation, welcome to Men of War: Assault Squad 2!

Let's therefore good order. The Men of War Assault Squad 2 is not a campaign in the true sense, but here is instead a system similar skirmish battles as in other RTS games. Thus, one can select from five different parties to the conflict WW2. Namely, these are Germany, the United States, the British Empire, the Soviet Union and finally the Japanese empire. It all sounds very good, the choice is really varied, at least ostensibly, but now back to reality.
Men of War Assault Squad Menu

Mission unfortunately are not only similar, but directly consistent with those for the other fraction. Thus, for example, in the first mission for the US must take part of the map, then show prestrihová animation, which will be destroyed by Allied tank and the game will offer you this tank repair and steal it. Lala him in the first mission for the Germans, which, however, takes place during the battle for North Africa there is the same situation and that is, the player conquers the part of the map, then appears prestrihová animation where the tank of your ally destroyed and you will be offered a repair appropriation of this machine. Really great, so that was not enough, some of these maps are taken already from the previous games Men of War Assault Squad, where the first mission in the US was on the same map as the second mission in the Assault Squad 2, namely in Normandy during the D day . I do not now just the same situation, so check out, but the same map with the same layout of buildings, soldiers, and just to all, that copy 1: 1, even with the same voice in speech, the Commander, which gives you the same commands, as in the previous parts!
Men of War Assault Squad

So innovative we point zero and even more below. Let's summarize but also other parts of the game. In principle, the game works on the same basis as its predecessor. Thus, the player starts on the map, which is littered with enemy units and always after the conquest of a certain part of the map was made available to the new unit, which the player can call for support. At the beginning of the map is therefore possible to call you only infantry teams, support teams, such as mortars and machine guns, then it is possible to summon support for light vehicles and, ultimately, tanks, or even aviation and artillery salvos. Depending on the selected difficulty is then derives the procedure on these maps, which will make the enemy attacks to have captured points, or the player that was tormented lightning counterattack, respectively. well coordinated offensive. This whole artificial intelligence and the behavior of units is not completely copied already from the first game.

Graphically the game looks almost identical to the previous work and there is no appreciable forward. The only corrections waited icons infantry teams, where orange, or yellow tape over their character sygnalizuje ability to deal with vehicles, so they carry a kind of form of anti-tank weapons, such as. German Panzerschreck or British anti-tank rifle Boys. Yes, this is the only real change from the previous episode! Mowas2 icon

Audio is well and where each faction has dubbed voices and various commands directly under the jurisdiction of their nation. This means that the Germans will speak German, Japanese will again use the Japanese language, and the like. This element, however, there is again no longer from the previous part. Nadôvažok, all voices used in this game are recycled as different from the previous work and even music in the opening menu is identical, respectively. copied from Men of War Assault Squad!

Men of War Assault Squad 2 is a disappointment and a colossal dimensions. Studio, which stands for the development of this game is no great AAA studio subsidized milionovej huge investments of its multi-million publisher, but this is really unforgivable. Selling the same game, with almost zero innovation, copying all files from previous work and selling de facto the same game, just updated to the new build is such a thing unheard of and be ticked off even before it was seizing other studies and other publishers . If you're a fan of strategies and the Second World War, so I prefer to buy the first episode, because Men of War Assault Squad is definitely worth it. If you have not already played or own previous works, so choose carefully if you want to invest a further circa 30 € to its exact copy.

reviewText:
I really want to like this game. It could be way better than company of heroes in that its more realistic, focuses more on actual combat, way more variety of units especially tanks, more countries to play as and so on. Unfortunately everytime I play it doesn't take long until I get annoyed and frustrated with it. If the developers can fix some of these issues with the game it will severely improve the experience. Here are my reasons I dislike this game:

1. The vehicle pathfinding is really frustrating. The vehicles will often drive into trees and get stuck, or take the most illogical routes through a village possible.
2. Tanks are pratically useless. Forget the terrifying panzers feared by allied infantry during ww2, because in this game almost all infantry can just spam attack them with AT grenades and destroy them instantly.
3. There is no notification that your units are under attack. This always happens to my defended positions. The game doesn't tell you anything, I will often look away for 10 seconds and look back and all my squads are dead.
4. Smoke grenades are useless. I don't know what their current in game function is but the certainly dont provide cover from enemy machinegunners.
5. The infantry ai are really dumb. I don't feel like I'm commanding real soldiers, but instead stiff robotic drones that require me to tell them to duck when under fire or move away when a grenade is right at their feet. Apparently none of these soldiers have instincts or basic training. They often will run straight into enemy fire for no reason and get killed when trying to throw a grenade rather than crawl, and take forever to fire a rocket launcher at a tank, usually just standing there frozen.
6. Some of the specialty units suck. When I saw you could get paratroppers I assumed you could drop them in behind enemy lines, but instead the just spawn exactly where everything else does. Kind of a let down.

reviewText:
Men of War Assault Squad 2 - in my opinion the current best (and hardest) RTS game with a  WW2 setting.

The game features a lot of missions split up between the 5 different nations. Germany, GB, USA, Japan & Sovjet Russia. While the pattern for the missions is the same they do play entirely different due too the different maps & nations.
Defend - attack - defend is what the first mission, more like tutorial mission, is like. Every other mission is either attack or defend. You have to capture outposts, reach waymarks and defend hills & important places. Easy, yet challenging.

There is no base building involded - you gain new units via reinforcement points or by capturing enemy tanks. Yes, capturing enemy tanks. Each and every one of your units can be split up, managed individually, forged into a new squad, has his own inventory, can be used with manual aim [...].
Including tanks! Tanks can be used with minimum manpower - the driver only. Or you can fully stack up and even place infantry on the back of the tank for faster movements. Its entirely up to you.
You units can switch weapons, ammo & special items, you can loot dead enemies to gain new weapons and ammo [...] the possibilitys are endless.

What is the challenging part of all this? Sounds rather nice, doesnt it?
The challenging part is the micromanagement, map awareness and realism. Tanks who get to close to trenches full of infantery - one AT grenade to his engine and hes busted.

Infantery running over an open field - on mg salvo, all dead.

The game does everything right that can be done right - a solid 10/10!
voteText: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Men of War:Assault Squad 2 is the most INDEPTH rts I've seen in my entire life.

For someone looking to experience an authentic World War II RTS, this game is for you. The developers at Digitalmindsoft have been blessed by the PC gods and have managed to bestow us this masterpiece. Why do I like this game so much? I think one of the major selling points was the GARGANTOUS range of options. I am specifically referring to the mouth watering stash of firearms, light tanks, medium tanks, HEAVY tanks, fighter planes, destroyers(big boats) and the diverse types of ammunition that accompany them. Not convinced yet? Then take a look at the cover system in place, allowing the player to cleverly place infantry so that they can take advantage of their surroundings. But forget all that. Who even cares if you can control every freaking infantry, vehicle, and weapon known in this game? Who cares if you can dump 20 hours of playing time just in the editor mode making crazy scenarios and reenacting battles? If you're not convinced by now, then my words haven't done the game justice. Check it out for yourself if you won't take my word. Chances are, you'll be as impresssed as I was and still am.

LAST BUT NOT LEAST

If you're going to play multiplayer, bring some lube.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been playing the closed beta since release date and after 3 patches its looking much better...

Overall its a big improvement over Assault Squad 1 with the main differences being visual quality and the interface.

The use of much newer shaders and multi cpu core support has improvewd the game to a huge degree.. IMHO anyways...

The AI seems much smarter and this may be a benefit of multi core support as everyting isnt being computed by just one cpu core ( This is the first game in the series to utilises more than 1 CPU core )

Due to the better performance everything seems much quicker and smoother and more realistic....

New vehicle models look much cleaner and more detailed with the new 3D models and shaders...

I have noticed the following improvements that some might see as trivial but overall they make for a better game... IMHO

- Vehicle crews board and unboard vehicles more quickly....
- Grenade throws are quicker ( in manual control mode anyway )
- Vehicle crews will look for a nearby repair kit if they are told to repair a vehicle and repair kit is not in vehicle...
- Ammo out icon for soldiers is great.....
- Vehicle damage icon is great...
- Vehcile reloading icon on sqaud icon is great..
-  New squad icons that show individual soldiers health status is also great.
- Inventory exchange bug crash from all previous games is  fixed...
- Transferring ammo between vehicles is less likely to result in the two vehicles crashing into each other.
- Mortar crews move a bit faster when told to move with the mortar.
- Mortar AI seems better, You can now use a sniper or officer with binoculars to spot targets and the mortar will engage more wi;;ingly.
- Repairs are quicker.
- Grouped soldiers / squads move more smoothly and try to keep the original placement in the squad ( rough formation ) when told to move.
- Dying / death animaytions seem more varied and more realistic..
- Soldiers loose their helmets less than previous games... ( no more constanty picking up helmets micro managment )
- Transferring ammo to a whole squad from a dead soldier or ammo crate is more intelligent,  it gives the correct ammo to the correct soldier ( in most cases ) based on the weapon they are carrying. ( and doesn't crash the game like MOW and AS1 did.. )
- Mine laying seems quicker..
- Steam workshop support is a great feature because it will make sharing content easy for everyone..

All of my observations are from playing single player missions only and don't reflect the Multi player / Cooperative modes of the game....

reviewText:
The game is an unimaginative rehash of first MoW:AS, has no campaign to speak of (there is a single-player mode, but it has no story, instead focusing on tug-of-war style gameplay that gets old after 10 minutes) and in every way the same or inferior to previous Men of War titles. There is no new content at all, and no new functionality, barring Steam Workshop support.
Constant crashes and unacceptable performance for an engine that was used half a dozen times already (I have nothing against GEM, but there is no excuse for time-tested engine like GEM to drop to 3 FPS in multiplayer), with braindead tech support team that seems to get their answers from Steam community forums doesn't help either.
Hell, the fact that the devs shut down MoW:AS servers so anyone at all would buy AS2 should speak for itself. MoW:AS2 is akin to a mod, there is no way in hell this can be called a new game.

TL;DR
♥♥♥♥♥♥ game, incompetent devs, buy MoW/FoW instead.

reviewText:
If you've played Men of War: Assault Squad 1, you won't find any surprises here.
Some new art assets, but no new gameplay or differing modes.
Most of the maps are directly lifted from AS1.
So is the interface.
...i think the maps are even listed in the same order.

As with the first, you can individually complete the skirmish maps, but there is no campaign to speak of, and no attempt is made to link the map you just finished with the following one.
I really enjoyed the original Assault Squad and happily clicked my way through its map list, it was new and fresh...by the end of the list, however, I was happy it was over. The missions are formulaic and tedious.

I'm 4 maps into Assault Squad 2 and I'm already tired of the forumula.
(holding out for reinforcements while being able to order as many tanks and troops as I like doesn't even make sense)


I'm not sure what I was expecting, but this just seems a stale reinterpretation of Assault Squad 1.

Wait for a $5 sale.

MoW: Assault Squad 2 is a very tecnical game, you need to position troops over a huge map and acomplish multiple objectives in a single stage to achieve victories, the character models are too small and the map is too big, its a dream come true if you have the patience to carefully observe all angles and possible positions for your army, but otherwise its a bit of a nightmare, i dont generally complain about the blessings a game bestows upon us gamers, but this game is a bit too hard to micromanage for normal people.

If you love strategy games, this is just like Commando (the old squad strategy game were you had to use only 4 characters to destroy entire german bases), in that winning maps takes minute planning, except in here you get to field an entire army, in much bigger map, which expands as you clear objectives (so you cant plan ahead too much sometimes)

Its a great game, its just a bit too much consuming and quite big on micromanaging. I suggest you try it if its still free on steam when you read this review.
voteText: 22 of 37 people (59%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Playing Campaign/Coop on Normal Difficulty:

Enemy AI has greater accuracy and range, your unit doesn't shoot back until enemy units are closer. Most of the time you'll have to micromanage them or they will get themselves killed, even when you're at an advantageous postion/cover, you're still f#%%ed.

Enemy light armor vehicle/tank will beat your medium/heavy armor tank most of the time, even when they're shooting you at the front of your tank's armor (which should be the strongest point of a tank). Enemy jeep with a mounted machine gun will withstand more punishment than your medium tank.

There's no real tactical advantage in spawning certain unit/armor. You can lose them to almost any type of the enemy units. This game is unsensibly hard and most of the time you'll be wondering how you lost a unit and/or cursing. There's more frustration than enjoyment.

I have not tried multiplayer matches enough to form a reasonable opinion. For those who want to play co-op with friends, I don't recommend it.

reviewText:
Here is my honest review.

I have been playing MOW a long time, and have enjoyed it quiet well. AS2 on the other hand I didn't like. It's trash. Plain and simple. Campaign is litterally the same as MOWAS with the DLC missions included. You have to pay money to get new campaigns and features that they should've implemeted when the game came out. Multiplayer is the same way. No new maps, and you have to pay to get new ones. Out synce errors that they have said they have fixed MULTIPLE times, but never have. The gameplay is garbage compared to MOWAS. Then theres the workshop. It was going really good, until they made some patch, that required mods to update when every minor patch came out, that didn't even affect the mod. The only reason I have so many hours in this game, is due to mods. The mods, made this game good, plain and simple. Honestly, all this game is a money horder.

So would I recommend this game?
Nope.

reviewText:
I know that a lot of people are saying that this game is a copy of the first assault squad. The 2 have some similarities, but there are also some differences.The units and tanks do look the same. They have added a few units but not very many. I know that this game is a sequel, which means that the game should be similar, but this game looks REALLY SIMILAR.
Pros:
-The game has pretty good gameplay and quite a few levels.
-The game is very addictive.
-There are many different types of units and countries to play as.
-There are probably 50 different tanks, and each one feels very different from the others.

Cons:
-This game is bascially a reskin of the first one. Some of the maps are nearly identical, and many of the units are the same.
-This game has some of the worst voice acting that I have ever heard. Since when did German field commanders have American accents?
-This game is too expensive when compared to teh first which is much cheaper and very similar.

Summary:
Although the game is good, it is basically a copy and paste of the first and seems to be a cash grab. I just picked the first one up and a whole bunch of DLC on sale for $5. Just buy the 1st one and save yourself a lot of money. I give this game a 5/10.

reviewText: This game looks beautiful. But its an unruly beast to control. You are basically controlling a section against companies of enemy, which is OK, but you have your hands full fighting a floating camera, and imbedded menus within a realtime environment where time flows too fast for the micro management involved. Even with pausing and performing actions while paused something seems off. I could buy this game today for $8.97 on a weekend sale, but I wouldn't get much fun out of it having downloaded a 24 hour trial I have determined its not for me. Its a shame they can't  re-vamp this game because it really looks awesome and its a scale of game I typically enjoy.  I've played a few of this series before, like faces of war, men of war 1, in a similar seed but found not much has changed,  too scripted for my liking.

reviewText: Guess this game is nice if you just want to jump into a match. There is no actual campaign though, which is disappointing. The skirmishes just throw you into a conflict without any regards to knowledge. You can watch YouTube clips for the tutorial. Out of 10 I would give this game a 5. It is good to the point that the tactics are solid, the graphics are nice. The UI could use some work as it isn't clear how to quickly switch from one squad to the next without manually doing it. If there was a campaign with an actual story line that lead to a destination then I would totally buy this game. But I don't have the time to watch all the videos in order to teach myself this game just to play against far superior players. This game feels more like an early access than a complete game due to all the key RTS factors that it doesn't have.

reviewText:
I would really like to give this game a 'thumbs up' but I am quite anooyed at how the devs have released DLC after DLC instead of the FREE UPDATES they promised. The most meaningful 'update' I have seen added the ability for units to auto re-supply. Oh, and they added a tank that is pretty terrible. Apart from that I havent noticed any change in the game since launch. Also, the AI in the game is still terrible, sometimes my AT troops will break cover and run up to a tank and get mowed down, instead of firing the launchers they have. I have over 300hrs on AS1 and to be honest this is the same game with a few new SP missions. On the MP side, I have yet to fully experience it as I have NEVER BEEN ABLE TO JOIN A MULTIPLAYER MATCH. Googling for my problem results in millions of results for 'MOW AS2 Out of sync error'. This issue has still not been fixed for 1000s of people since launch. I feel pretty bad that I convinced my friend to buy this so we could play together only to discover none of us can join any MP matches. The editor is very fun and is where I spend most of my time, but it is almost the same as AS1 in most aspects.

HOWEVER, This is still a fun game (if you like spending 3 days to make a decent looking map to have fun battles on against the ai you have to script every move and action for) and this is indicated by my high playtime on both titles. I heard the devs recently added AI to MP mathces (Which should have been a free update not DLC) and from what I hear, it is pretty terrible.

Would still play this over COH2 though.

verdict (without editor): 4/10
(with editor)      : 6/10
(forgetting multiplayer ever existed) : 8/10

reviewText:
I only tried the game when it was playable for free for a few days. Not much of a strategy player, yet I HAVE played some in the past, and the problem for me, with this one, was that I was totally lost right away. The mission objectives are quite clear, the UI isn't too cluttered, yet I still didn't know how to actually control my soldiers.
I'd try to get some to throw grenades, marked several at once to take out an enemy shooter, etc, and it only worked like a quarter of the time. I'd try all kinds of combinations (left click, mouse click, function keys), yet never was sure whether I am supposed to manage each soldier individually, command a small group, and how exactly to get them to actually do a certain thing.
I looked for a tutorial, and all I found was a bunch of short youtube videos linked in game, which didn't help much either.
Call me a total idiot, if you like, and no, I didn't try the first MoW. But I think if the developer is trying to get new players to join in this day and age (call it the idiot age where people do like tutorials to learn the controls instead of watching youtube vids or googling for a guide), they might wanna give newcomers some clue on how to actually control your troops correctly, without them having to try by trial and error how to even make a soldier throw a grenade. ANY indicator would help.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

703 Hours of playing Men of war Assult Squad 1. After playing 2, I noticed right away that theres no reload option for my units. Infact there are less options all around. You can imagine for a player who enjoys absolute control this was quite a let down. I also noticed that the company icons look alot like company of heros unit icons. I played the entire first mission through the Americans and to my suprise after capturing 2 flags i still couldn't recruit a morter team nor could I recruit an mg team and when i recruited a ranger team instead of coming in a half track like they usually do they came on foot. Im greatly frusterated because to me in feels like they have gone backwards and taken away more then improved it. As a devoted fan there are many things already about this game that really make it feel like company of heros 2. If you were to ask me if you should buy this i would definitly wait for it to be finished, im extremely unhappy about what iv'e seen as of now.

reviewText:
Game is broken, has been broken and likely will always be broke. Cash grabs like this often have little effort put into them.

This is nothing more than AS1 with broken promises, a community Czar, and a defunct online system. Save your money!

I gave this game every chance, I have been banned on the forums numerous times for expressing my concern in a civil manner; they simply don't care and don't want the bad press.

I am thankful this game was gifted to me, but I am sorry someone wasted their money on it.

Don't be fooled by these cons and tricksters.

The Store page is a misleading representation of the game, planes are only in the single player and skirmish missions ( which are horrible)

Mulitplayer has the SAME EXACT units as AS.

Game is crap, company is crap.

This is a great game, after you get passed all of the issues.  The game is still plauged with out of syncs that have been there for over 5 months now.

The performance you get in multiplayer is dictated almost entirely by other people's PCs.  My friend with a gtx 970 is laging on this game but it works fine on singleplayer because there arent other players.  I am also getting a gtx 970 so I will update this and see how it works for me.

The Editor:  Holy ♥♥♥♥ is this awesome,  you can make your own maps and missions with it, im currently making some myself and it feels just great.

The Graphics:  The game's units are out rageously outdated.  some of the tank models actually havent been updated sense men of war 1 (almsot 6 years ago).  The infantry skins are rather poor, all you need to do is look for some on the steam workshop and they look signifigantly better than the ones in this game.

At the current time I cant say I recommend this game, I wish that a bigger team was working on it and had the budget to make this game what it deserves to be.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I played th Beta, and the second skirmish misson for the U.S. is completely broken. Towards the end, you have to get to an extraction point. Simple enough, except it's guarded by an anti-aircraft gun that can see you for miles, and you can't get close enough to take it out. There are three tanks in the level, but the game won't let you take them. You also, have a fixed amount of points, and when I got to the end of the level, I was only able to call in Officers (They literally can't do anything), a single medic (slightly less useless at the point I was at), and snipers (Very useful normally). Funnily enough, it's impossible to shoot off the gunner from the front, and there's no spot I could get to that was behind it, or to the side of it. On top of that, tanks continued to spawn, making the situation worse. If I'm buying a game from you, I should actually be able to play it, instead of just losing, almost automaticly. I'm serverly dissapointed, especially since when I bought it, there were numerous games on sale, invluding the ENTIRE rockstar collection. I could've bought half of them for the same price of this game, but I liked the first Assualt Squad, and was so excited for this one, I wanted to get a little cheaper, and make sure I got it.

To summarize, broken level, automatic failure, frustration, anger.

reviewText:
First off, let me begin by stating that I purchased the complete edition of this game when it was on sale for $10. If you already have the original Men of War: Assault Squad, I don't reccomend buying this game for full price. Wait until it goes on sale and grab the complete edition.

Alright, now that I've gotten that out of the way, let me begin my review. :)

This game is awesome, and for RTS lovers, a must buy. The detail is great and the options for battlefield tactics are unlimited. I haven't played a RTS that handles combat as well this does. If you're a Star Wars fan, get the Galaxy at War mod. It'll completely blow away the land battles in Empire at War.

Lastly, this game runs very well on my laptop. I have a Nvidia GeForce GT 640M (1GB Dedicated GDDR5) and I'm getting 60+ fps with little action and 30+ when the fighting is heavy on medium settings. Overall I reccomend this game to all RTS lovers.

reviewText: This game makes me hate two specific groups of people.  First: big game developers who prove once again that by throwing heaps of money at promotion (I’m looking at you CoH 2) their game can outperform superior games.  And second, people who aren’t willing to put in the effort to learn a new game because it’s hard.  There is no question that MOWAS II is a thinking man’s game.  To be good you have to know armor values, penetration chances, gun calibers, and much more.  You have to invest your points in the right units, know how to use cover, and give your troops good lines of sight.  One mortar shell will kill and entire squad if you bunch them up behind a sandbag because, well, that’s reality.  Remember that veteran tiger that you saved up all game for?  You didn’t support it with infantry so it died to one AT grenade in less than 2 minutes.   It’s not CoH 2, or rather a glorified game of rock, paper, scissors, you actually have to think.  I already know people will say ‘yeah that’s all well and good but who has the time to learn all that?’ and it’s a weak argument.  If you’re going to invest a day of your life into a game anyway what is another five or six hours to learn how to play it well? The point it this is a fantastic game.  Take the time to learn it and come have some fun.

reviewText: It might be fun, but I'll never know. There is literally no help learning to play the game. There are some hints that give you strategies or tell you about a specific feature or two, and there is a library of YouTube videos which all explain some of the more complex tasks, but there is no tutorial, introduction, sandbox, or anything like that: you're on your own, and it's trial-and-error. That wouldn't be so bad if the game were a simplistic shooter or a more traditional Age-of-Empires-style RTS: you could guess at the controls and probably get them right enough to play. This, however, is an incredibly in-depth game with a lot of micromanagement that gives you no information about how to find or use its features. It's also a strange combination of realism (various systems on armour which can all be disabled, various weaponry with unique stats and ballistics, etc.) and absurdism (a Thompson with a range of 50 meters, 10+ hits to kill a person, etc.). Like so many others, this game completely ignores the most significant part of a game: teaching the player how to play it. If you have nothing else to do, or if you enjoy spending most of your time reading about your new game rather than playing it, you can probably learn Men of War: Assault Squad 2 in a couple days. Otherwise, skip it and wait till the publisher gets serious.

reviewText:
Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is probably the worst gay porn I’ve played. Though it looks exciting and sounds fun, and moves hard and rapidly, it rarely gets me off.

People have been saying that THIS entry in the series is supposed to be the multiplayer, coop one. And I (usually) love watching guys tongue each other’s ♥♥♥♥♥ with my friends just like everyone else does. But what if I told you that the American scenes in this collection are basically the same as the German ones, which are basically the same as the Japanese ones, which are basically the same as the British ones, and the Russian ones? All five of the nations. What if I told you that the sniper (or optionally commandos) scene for the U.S. is repeated four times with the other nations? And also the same for the defense scenes? And also the advance-across-the-set scenes? What if I told you that instead of the 40, original group sex scenes advertised on this store page, you get, actually, just 8 that are (arguably) original? And now, forget the what ifs; because it’s true.

These 15 and 25 scenes are actually just eight. Different actors for each nation? Sure. But the interracial variety isn’t enough.

What about the Steam Workshop mods? Well I played two of the top-rated ones, SirHinkel’s AS2 Missions and RobZ’s Base Defense ones. And they do suck ♥♥♥, but not in a good way.

SirHinkel’s missions are his interpretations of famous man-on-man actions, including a very well-realized The Alamo orgy, from the epic gay porn film Saving Private Ryan. And though Italian and Hungarian men join the action during SirHinkel’s Stalingrad orgies, they’re almost all just long slogs. You can certainly set the intensity of the boning (Easy, Medium, etc.), but instead of more exciting moments of drama, you usually get merely longer scenes. And sure some people like long, hard sex scenes before the actors get so tired that, finally, they all just exhaustedly come onto each other’s throbbing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. But let’s be real: the best gay porn follows the quality-over-quantity standard. SirHinkel DID put a lot of strategic thought into his scenes, with many good placements for many dangerous toys, but as for the great climactic moments, when you just want to ejaculate while the actors do: well, they rarely happen, and (strangely) they usually do so near the beginning of his scenes. So it’s just hours of repetitive hard ♥♥♥♥ing, until it’s finally, suddenly over.

As for RobZ’s base defense scenes, you look at their descriptions and think you’re in for a really good time. You start playing one and lay your initial men in comfy spots, waiting for the other nation’s uniformed-men to creep up and come on them. But it’s all ruined by what must be two bugs. Specifically: when you call in more of your dudes to join the orgy, they (infuriatingly) WALK, and unenthusiastically. And on top of or under that: these men will change their destination to wherever you tell the next boys you call in. So you have to manually look at the troops as they walk onto the scene and jerk them into running to where you actually want them. And on large set pieces, where the defenses are far from where you call in the new boys, it Just Makes Masturbation a Chore, as you move the screen across the map, clicking the walking unit, moving across the map to where you really want them, double right-clicking that spot so they run to THAT SPOT, repeat...

No gay porn should soften one's ♥♥♥♥ this much...

And what about the player-on-player multiplayer? Is it fun to jerk-off with someone across the Internet, or with your friend next to you? Not compared to the Company of Heroes multiplayer it isn't. MoW: ♥♥♥ Sqd 2 favors realism too much, and doesn’t understand something important about gay porn (or porn in general): Realistic Sex is not what we want to watch. I mean, for realism just go do the real thing. In pornography you want to see lots of herculean men doing all kinds of crazy ♥♥♥♥ to each other’s holes. It’s called FANTASY sex. This understanding is shown by Relic in their Company of Heroes (Vanilla edition). Men of War: Assault Squads 1 and 2 go too realistic, and thus make for undramatic man-on-man action
date: over and over and over.\n\nIn conclusion: for gay, WW2-themed cream pies and facials, play Company of Heroes instead. (I haven’t played Company of Heroes 2; feel free to comment if you have an opinion about its ♥♥♥♥♥-rubbing-♥♥♥♥♥ action)

reviewText:
The game is pretty good if you are into WW2 RTS and micromanaging but there is so much that could be improved.

In vanilla I would have given it a recommend if you want a more realistic and micro managment intensive WW2 RTS than CoH2. With their attitude towards DLCs I have to say avoid.

reviewText: The Men of War series is one of my favorite PC games ever. This installment is just a polished MoW Assault Squad I, rereleased with a few extra bells and whistles. On sale, it's worth $10-$20, and if you're a fan of the series than it's worth a little more. It's RTS, squad-control, and micro-management to the extreme. I love being able to control a whole squad, or tank, all the way down to a single infantry man who can pick up a dropped grenade, ammo clip, or check a fallen soldiers inventory. I recommend it for fans of Dawn of War II, CoH's, and the Total War series.\n\n

reviewText:
UPDATE 22/02/2014

The game has been transformed in some kind of test ape for DMS future product: Call of Arms. Features, which have little or no benefit for MOW, are rushed in a pre-alpha status and they have completely broken the game. Many people can not start the game, most of the people are suffering frequently crashes. Finishing a 2v2+ game is impossible.

After one year from release the game fundamentals, like stability and lag, are still broken and nothing let us think they will be fixed. I waited one year in the hope that items for which the game was sold would be fixed. But this is the status today:

- steam integration (to start the game you have to deactivate steam overlay)
- improved graphics ( maybe a little on some machine)
- steam multiplayer (broken)
- matchmaking (broken)
- 8v8 on spectacular maps( no 8v8 on sight and maps are the same as 5 years ago also they changed the store page to 4v4)

My opinion over the gameplay remains unchanged: when played the game is fun, but currently it just can't be played therefore I don't feel like suggesting to buy it, it has no future.

reviewText:
Almost my whole squad was mowed down by a machinegunner.
I took control of the last surviving member of the squad, healed him and equipped him with some of it's dead teammates weapons and completed the mission with him.

10/10 would Rambo again



But seriously, it's a WWII realtime strategy game with more realistic mechanics than for example Company of Heroes. Each soldier is truly an individual with his own health and inventory (which you can modify). You can squad them up and move them as a squad or send each individual to a specific location.

Ammunition and fuel run out and you have to resupply your forces, you can micromanage each individual soldier or do it as a squad.

Tank mechanics are a bit different than soldier mechanics. Tanks don't have healthbars. Instead, if you for example destroy the engine or turret, it can't drive or move it's turret respectively. The penetration mechanics are also more realistic. If you play Warthunder, it's a simplified version of the one you're used to in Ground Forces.
Tanks, as do all vehicles, must be crewed by soldiers. The crew can be knocked out. If a tank doesn't have a gunner, it can't aim and fire it's gun. The crew will automatically try to fill the most vital spots, so it's possible to have a tank with one crewmember that switches between seats as needed, although this is of course far less efficient than a fully crewed tank.

But one of the most interesting features is the ability to 'ASSUME DIRECT CONTROL'of a soldier or vehicle. Making it a sort of top-down 3D shooter..thingamajigger.

When I'm playing a singleplayer game I often get the feeling I'm a small part of a large scale battle. You usually get control over a squad or two and sometimes some vehicles. And when you force a breakthrough, your allies will pour through it and take advantage of it.

And there is also a powerful map editor that is easy to understand, so there are a lot of maps made available by skilled editors.

TL;DR Buy this game or bad things will happen to your pet ostrich named George V.

True story

reviewText:
Almost my whole squad was mowed down by a machinegunner.
I took control of the last surviving member of the squad, healed him and equipped him with some of it's dead teammates weapons and completed the mission with him.

10/10 would Rambo again



But seriously, it's a WWII realtime strategy game with more realistic mechanics than for example Company of Heroes. Each soldier is truly an individual with his own health and inventory (which you can modify). You can squad them up and move them as a squad or send each individual to a specific location.

Ammunition and fuel run out and you have to resupply your forces, you can micromanage each individual soldier or do it as a squad.

Tank mechanics are a bit different than soldier mechanics. Tanks don't have healthbars. Instead, if you for example destroy the engine or turret, it can't drive or move it's turret respectively. The penetration mechanics are also more realistic. If you play Warthunder, it's a simplified version of the one you're used to in Ground Forces.
Tanks, as do all vehicles, must be crewed by soldiers. The crew can be knocked out. If a tank doesn't have a gunner, it can't aim and fire it's gun. The crew will automatically try to fill the most vital spots, so it's possible to have a tank with one crewmember that switches between seats as needed, although this is of course far less efficient than a fully crewed tank.

But one of the most interesting features is the ability to 'ASSUME DIRECT CONTROL'of a soldier or vehicle. Making it a sort of top-down 3D shooter..thingamajigger.

When I'm playing a singleplayer game I often get the feeling I'm a small part of a large scale battle. You usually get control over a squad or two and sometimes some vehicles. And when you force a breakthrough, your allies will pour through it and take advantage of it.

And there is also a powerful map editor that is easy to understand, so there are a lot of maps made available by skilled editors.

TL;DR Buy this game or bad things will happen to your pet ostrich named George V.

True story

reviewText: I have been quite the fan of Men of War. I love RTS and I love WWII, so its perfect for me. One thing to note is that this game can be incredibly complex. The amount of micro you CAN put into this game can be quite insane. Every single unit has an inventory, ammunition, tanks/vehicles have fuel that runs out. It can all be resupplied from trucks or dead troops or vehicles. This game is tons of fun and extremely realistic. There really isnt much of a singleplayer campaign/story its more of just challenge skirmishes that you can play by yourself or with friends. Do not get me wrong it can be incredibly fun. This game takes time to learn, but it is one of the most rewarding gaming experiances ever. I love it. Here is the difficult thing, it really isnt much of a step up from the first Men of War Assault Squad. Yes they included all the DLC maps that they sold to people in the first one, and there are new units and it handles slightly better than its predecessor but not by much. The game is in need of a new engine badly, the games engine cannot handle how complex the physics are. Other than that if you are aware that it really isnt a sequel but more of an update/expansion? I guess and you know what your getting into then go for it pick it up. Other than that don't buy it unless its on a sale if you have the first.\n8.5/10

reviewText: Its the exact same as Assault Squad 1.  All the same skirmish missions with a few extra added in that are new.  It says that in the description and I knew this but I thought they would at least revamp the old missions and add a greater selection of units that they added.  Instead I must trudge through the old missions to get to the new.  The other thing I do not like at all about either game is that each skirmish mission for each country is EXACTLY the same format.  A little variety here and there and perhaps a bit more uniqueness when it comes to the different countries would be fantastic.  Things that feature the strengths and weaknesses of a country perhaps.  I just cannot recommend this game but if you do not have either and absolutely want to buy it then do not get both 1 and 2.  As 2 is all you would need and should have been the only one released.  I knew what I was getting to some point but I still feel robbed of my money.

reviewText:
Here's the deal:

This game is identical in almost every aspect to the first MoW: AS. The maps are identical, the controls are identical, the UI is (mostly) identical, etc. However, the first AS is very old. If you're like me you put hundreds of hours into it by now and have probably even stopped playing it because you've done everything there was to do. I was at that point with the first one and hadn't opened it up in over three months because I was tired of it, until I saw this go on sale for 60% off.

I figured Hey
recommended: I get the full deluxe edition for $15 and I will be able to play Assault Squad again even if it's the same damn game." As long as you know going into it that this is just an updated version of the first one
hoursPlayed: you will be fine and enjoy it. Do not expect anything new from the single player aspect other than a couple UI changes and (somewhat) better voice acting. The voice acting in the first one was so terrible though it wasn't hard to improve on. The only real changes are the focus on Steam and multiplayer. Steam Workshop means this game will stay fresh for a very long time with new content from users and it has all the bells and whistles of modern Steam games like cards to collect
voteText: XP to earn
helpfulPercent: in-game achievements to show off
votesHelpful: etc.\n\nThe other noticeable change is the difficulty level. Remember how ridiculously hard the first AS was on Hard mode? I literally rage quit dozens of times because the difficulty level was ABSURD. This game.. not so much. The Hard mode feels like Normal mode from AS. Heroic here is basically Hard mode there. This is a good thing in my opinion because it now allows hardcore fans like me to earn Heroic achievements because they were unattainable in the first. I wouldn't even try Heroic mode in the original one because I figured the AI had pocket nuclear missiles and a time machine to warp stealth fighters and gauss cannons back to beat my ♥♥♥ with. If you ever completed the single-player campaign from AS on Heroic mode
votesTotal:
you should write a book about your endeavor and send me a copy.

TL;DR

Updated version of the first game. Difficulty turned down a few notches. Get this on sale and don't expect a whole new game.

"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's basically an engine rewrite (multicore, new graphics) of the first MoW:AS, with shiny new models, 2 new(ish) tanks, and new missions made by a great community modder DJSatane (Much love, much respect). I've heard of some gameplay changes but I haven't noticed them.

He says DLC support will be greater, and hopefully the final game will be more stable (it crashes extremely often now). Hopefully older content will be easily ported to this.

I'd get it only if you're a hardcore MoW fan, otherwise wait until after release. Still, Assault Squad was probably the best multiplayer experience in the series and an improved version of it is probably worth getting in my book (provided stability issues are solved)

reviewText: MOWAS2 the great successor of the old soldier heroes of ww2. No RTS or RTT can get even close to this game. It is almost simulation with lot of physics in it. This game is the best ww2 themed game ever made and worth every penny. It is one of my favorite games. If you are a fan of arcades, animation with no military knowledge this game is made for soldiers and tacticians avoid it.

reviewText:
Pros:

-Great game and great gameplay
-Destruction system(how buildings fall,you can destroy everything to the ground)
-Lots of SP missions(even if they are copied versions for all nations) and achievements on every difficulty level
-I Love tank/vehicle battles in this game
-Experience/level unlock system
-Tanks/Antiair 20mm machineguns used on infantry :) they dying like they should not like in other stupid games (CoH)

reviewText:
Very good real-time strategy. It reflects the realities of World War 2 Moreover, the fate of the game can change even one soldier I can recommend 100%!
Of course, as every game has its pros and cons to mention below.
+ Strong emphasis on realism extra game is not easy is quite difficult and you have to toil.
+ Extensive vehicles with their damage, destruction, fuel, ammo which changes the very gameplay.
+ The ability to use the workshop
+ Models destruction and good physics
+ A large variety of units.
+ Unusual multiplayer games.
-Very Unfriendly game for beginners, both in playing the game and in the editor.
- Frequent crashes.
- Poor optimization of even the most powerful computers strong explosion is able to do the problem computer.
-Very Poor singleplayer campaign (fortunately, with the help of steam comes workshop)
In my opinion 8/10 because you have to remember that the game is in Beta and is still developing.

reviewText:
Love this game, just picked the full package up on the sale so im still green but this game is great fun...   its not like most other WW2 RTS.. make no mistake this game is not easy and there is a lot more to it than unit numbers...

Im running this on a toaster of a rig on medium and have no issues at all, so for you guys wondering if your old rig will run it here ya go...

E8400 CORE2DUO running at 3.6mhz

an old seagate HD thats about to explode...

hope that helps those on older rigs

reviewText: One of the best strategy games I have ever played. Being extremely tactical and realistic, it is also quite difficult; even the ammo assigned to each individual soldier is to be kept under control!\nTank battles are far more realistic than they are in other similar games; vehicles can be crewed and uncrewed, damages depend on the kind of shell, on the distance from the target and on the hit part. Covers are nice, and it is possible to control the soldiers' stance (standing up, prone and so on) manually. Enemy vehicles, if abandoned and not completely destroyed, can be recovered and stolen. Anti tank guns are really effective against tanks, but there is always a certain amount of randomness which makes everything unpredictable and suspencing. Every action has to be planned accurately, and unreasoned and silly moves are very likely to cause disastrous outcomes; there is a nice reinforcements mechanism which depends on the controlled checkpoints, and new weapons are available on the field after a new checkpoint has been conquered.\nThe only bad thing is that, during multiplayer battles, reinforcements are automatically split among players, causing messy situations (who called this sniper?" "Can I have your Panzer
date: or you desperately need it?"). It is possible to send units to an ally player
recommended: but this takes time and can be pretty annoying."

reviewText:
This game is my absolute favorite speaking of rts games.
it comes with all the options someone could ask for.
great map/mission editor inclusive.

You can have massive battles with tons of tanks and arty,
you can also have infantry squad based, storydriven stealhgameplay in
which you e.g. need to lead a group of airbornes to infiltrate a german flakbase.
You can also have both at the same time.

to top it all, the   multiplayer   is great. its possible to launch an 8vs8 battle,
though, it can causeserious lags and performance drops - depending on the match's option ofc. 2vs2, 3vs3 or 4vs4 is no problem most of the times. gamemodes are
battlezones (in which you need to capture flagzones, if you keep more than the enemy,
your team will gain points). combat (in which you get points for destroying enemy units)
and some variations of those. you can set the options like how high the pointscap will be,
the maximum of how many troops someone can call in or lead at once, etc all yourself.

hundrets of different vehicles and units like mortars, mgs, howitzers are awaiting you. the   content   is amazing. mods will deliver you even more, high detailed units or even whole factions.

micromanagment   is a big thing in this game, though you dont need to take care of each soldiers inventory (yes, thats actually possible). every soldier has a name, skills and his job. you would need to control a soldier to throw a nade into a good spot here and then, but most of the times you will find yourself controlling your favorite tank and hunt down others in direct mode.

speaking of   direct mode  , its the thing which seperates it from other ww2 rts games most, imo. you can, if you want, control single units in WASD mode, use the weapon or other items (even throwing knives for the fun of it). nothing is more satisfying than hitting an enemy tank into its ammo depot (the game is doing a great job in hitboxes) in direct mode, causing a huge explosion which will destroy the buildings around it, including the snipers in them. mmh. feels gud man.

if you want to make a map yourself, do it. the   editor   is a quite easy tool to make super detailed maps, waiting to get released on the workshop. there are plenty tutorials on youtube or on communityhub. i have created a few of them my own, its worth to get the game only for checking out my incredible beautiful maps.

the   mods   will let this game staying alive for long long time. star wars, realism mods, a mod in which you play the sp campaing of call of duty mw2, terminator mod schwarzenegger style, mods which will let you explore the modern war or just simple skinpacks or soundpacks - all available here on steamworkshop.
easy installation and setup.

if you now think   meh
date: all i was asking for is a simple rts game"
recommended:
its simple if you want. a simple rts game in which you can call in infantry and tanks to destroy the opposing
armies and conquer some ground. but you can go deeper if you like.
alot more deeper. and its always better to go deeper no homo.

if you want to learn more

reviewText:
If your a big fan of World War II games, or if you simply enjoy a good real time strategy, Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is definitely for you. Providing the player with five single-player campaigns and armies, Men of War is literally full of different units all of which are unique and are more or less historically accurate. The game always keeps you in strategic dicision making, and the direct firing control which was first introduced in Soldiers Heroes of World War II (a very old but awesome predecessor of this here fine title) makes tank duels an unmatched experience which you won't find in any other comparable RTS (like CoH 2 for an example).

What really makes this game valuable and gives many hours of gameplay is the multiplayer. There are many different maps and a decent amount of players. Due to the in-game physics, armor penetration chances, infantry maneuvers, gamestyles of the players, every match is never the same, so every single battle always becomes a new, unpredictable challange. The game also has many modes, so you can always play the one which fits your style, with strategic point control, casual combat and even cooperative missions all being present for you to enjoy. While competing in online battles, the player has the opprotunity to choose his own style of play. Tanks, infantry and artillery all fulfil their crucial roles in order to achieve victory, and all types of units require an individual commanding approach. Multiplayer is undoubtedly the most apparent upside of AS2.

Since the GEM engine is rather old, the graphics in this multiplayer strategy are a bit below the standards, especially if we start comparing this title to Company of Heroes 2. This, however, is compensated by the scale of the battlefields which are present in this game, with explosions and complete destruction of in-game objects all contributing to an astonishing overall image of war as it is shown in Assault Squad 2. In spite of graphics not being the bestest quality of this RTS, they are nevertheless pleasant to look at. The textures are neat, the models of the vehicles are very detailed, explosions and visual effects are dynamic, thus commiting to credibility. Out of anything more negative, i can only note the models and textures of the infantry, which haven't been updated since 2006 when Faces of War came out.

In general, Men of War: Assault Squad 2 can be recommended to anyone who wants to play a good quality WW2 RTS with a well developed multiplayer.

reviewText:
I know more people that have played Company of Heroes than Men of War, which is a shame because Men of War is to Company to Heroes what Arma is to Battlefield. GameplayFirst off: Men of War is a squad based WW2 Strategy Game. The game does not offer any base building but is centered around capturing command posts, which give you points, that you can then use to request squads of soldiers, tanks, airstrikes and the likes. Infantry Combat Every soldier in Men of War comes with his own inventory and his own weapons, which makes micromanagement a must. Troops need to remain supplied with ammunitions, bandages and grenades throughout the engagements which can either be scavenged from fallen enemies (or friends) or vehicles. Furthermore every weapon has its own advantages: SMGs are for medium and short range engagements, rifles for long ranges, LMGs to supress areas, sniper rifles, flamethrowers, pistols. You can move units individually or group them together in a squad depending on the situation.
Vehicle Combat Like infantry tanks have an inventory too. Unlike infantry, tanks also have different armor levels on all sides. Distance to tank, angle of shot, projectile used, and where the shell hits all make the difference between an AT shell that deflects off the tanks armor or disables one of its critical systems (turret, main gun, left or right tread, hull or motor). Remember that scene in Fury where the crew outmaneuvers a German Tiger? This game lets you do that.
Personal Control At any point in time you can push E and personally control a unit from the strategic view using WASD and your mouse. I personally wished it was in third person, but whatever. So if tank-mc-gee isn't doing what you want you can just take him over and position him yourself. Which brings me to my next point:
The environment: Men of War features very detailed countrysides, cities, and industrial maps which are all completely destructible. Tanks can drive through walls, explosions will destroy windows, vegetation can burn to the ground. A house can shield the flanks of your tank until a cannon lands a shot through the kitchen window. All vehicles, whether destroyed or not, can serve as cover to your units. Same is true for trenches, trees and sandbags (which will provide cover until they're blown apart).


Overall I think Men of War is the best squad based RTS out there. The level of realism is insane, the campaings are fun to play with friends (up to 8 player coop). Men of War 2 is more of a re-make of Men of War 1 but definitely adds some things like shared ammunition among squads and new scenarios. I can only recommend this game.

reviewText:
This game is both the best ww2 title out there and the worst disaster of a game at the same time.  It holds some great game elements as well as some absolute game design disasters. It is sad to see so much potential getting wasted.

First, the good stuff:
Let me begin by saying this: After playing this game for a bit, other titles like Company of Heroes really started to look like jokes.
Both infantry and armor gameplay are awesome.
The multiplayer game experience in itself is awesome. No other words for it. It has a very good tempo. The stakes are always high. So much can change in a split second. The balance between infantry and armor is top notch. The arcade element is there and it rewards good play. The best part is, this game is doing all this while keeping a very good amount of realism and detail.
All the factions that the game comes with. Like, really. I see so many people complaining about AI not being free. Ok maybe thats wrong but you guys realize that this is pretty much one of the few ww2 titles that comes with five factions right? Thats gotta mean something.
The mod support. There are mods featuring even the tiniest of ww2 factions. Wanna play as french in 1940? you got it. Would you prefer to play as Poland? Sure thing! You want the game to be much more spectacular and realistic? Tired ot the games linear and unimaginative skirmishes? Do you want to play with star wars factions? Hell, do you want a mod of a weeb anime about schoolgirls and tanks? You have it all. With all the mods there are out there, the vanilla game feels like a mere demo of the full experience. And make no mistake, the vanilla game still has a lot of content.
Yeah, it sounds awesome right, Now for the bad stuff:
Multiplayer matchmaking system. It's not just bad, it practically doesn't exist. You don't have any way to just hop in and play, you have to host a game, wait for people to join in (which takes so much as 20 minutes sometimes) and you have no idea if they are in your level or not. It can be a nice competitive match or just an absolute massacre. This is the result of trying to implement restricted units and having downright unimaginative stupid map designs for current ingame matchmaking system. A game like this shoud have had dedicated matchmaking for individual mods.
Too many settings for multiplayer. This is not supposed to be a problem, but when the matchmaking is broken, some people will never learn about the proper balanced settings of the game.
The skirmishes are linear and repetitive. If you want good single player content you have to go to the workshop.
The difficulty setting of the skirmishes are downright ridiculous. I mean seriously, changing damage infantry takes? I mean how dimwitted you have to be for not realising doing that changes the game's mechanics completely? Being able to run at a mechinegun fire just kills the games experience and gives the beginners wrong expectations about everything. Not to mention that it defeats the whole purpose of having a single player campaign which is primarily educating the player for full multiplayer experience.
Infantry animations look cheap. It is the first thing most of the newcomers will notice and it doesn't hold up with the rest of the game.
Bugs and out of sync issues. Which is much better by now but having constant out of snyc problems for more than year after the launch is pretty bad. Along with the broken matchmaking, this is the reason why so few people play it today.
DLCs are not well thought out. Seriously, mods are better.
The developers of this game made a great product but somehow it seems like they don't really understand what makes it so great. And they don't seem to understand some of the most fundamental gamer expectations. All that said, I would still recommend this game. Even with all the dlc's the price is a bloody steal for all the content it provides. BUT keep in mind that its rough around some of the edges that it really shouldn't have been.

reviewText:
Men of War: Assault Squad 2 features new single player style skirmish modes that take players from extreme tank combat to deadly sniper stealth missions.

Features:
– Direct control every unit as if you were playing a 3rd person shooter
– Interface and AI improvements, including unit kill counts and squad icon information
– New multiplayer interface
– Camouflage depending on season
– Fully updated inventory items with new graphics and updated vehicles
– Sound improvements, including voice acting
– Steam features, including Steam multiplayer, matchmaking, achievements, cloud, player statistics, leaderboards, voice chat, Valve anti-cheat, friends invite and workshop
– Player level up and ranked system
– In-game video recording, and much more.
– 15 new single player skirmishes plus 25 reworked ones from the original Assault Squad
– Eight player co-op support and an all new multiplayer extreme game mode
– 65 multiplayer maps and five gamemodes
– More than 250 vehicles at your command
– More than 200 soldiers with unique equipment
– Five factions and various battlefields in Europe, Eastern Europe, Northern Africa and the Pacific
– Development tools such as 3d model exporter and map/mission editor, and much more.

The Men Of War franchise has a very solid reputation and Men Of War: Assault Squad 2 not only lives up to it but raises the bar for all real-time strategy games.

If this is the style of game for you than this is a must play for you.

THE GOOD
+ Deep
+ Engaging gameplay
+ Huge amount of features

THE BAD
- Hard for newcomers

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Firstly i own all the men of wars, Vietnam and CH were horrible games, why?, because they were developed by 1C not Digitalmindsoft, Digitalmindsoft made the first MOWAS.

This is going to be a great sequal, i really like the idea that the game uses steam instead of gamespy. and ofc Steam workshop, its going to be amazing to see all the mods that will come from the workshop.

Yes its much like the first MOWAS in terms of units. BUT its in BETA so not everything is in the game, But there are a lot of new engine improvements that makes the game look amazing in terms of graphics, i have not experience any lag like the first men of war had, there are a few new game modes like day of victory in which you capture the flag that is located in the middle, extreme assault zones which is just a bigger assault zones.

I hear a lot of people complaning that its the same game, well in terms of units there isnt a lot you can add that was in world war 2, it isnt like call of duty were you can add a few more weapons, this game is based on world war 2, i do wish they could add everything from the German soldiers mod to MOWAS 2 because that had a lot of great units, and its only 21€ its not a 59.99€ release. if you arent sure that you like what you see right now, then dont buy it, wait until its complete, and remember its in beta a lot of things can still change.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is early access review.
In terms of the looks the game is not really that much different. Most of the animations, units etc look like in the first one and the feel of the game is the same.

There are some major improvements in the play already though and heres some of them. (Will keep adding info as more content comes availevable)
1)
Improved pathfinding. Doesnt sound like much does it? It is actually a really big difference the units infantry and vehicles alike no longer get stuck as easy and the game shows the path they will take so if you can correct the route so no longer running through that open area infront of the machine gun or straight to the minefield.
2)
More maps. Again not something major but for me who has played all maps 50 times seeing new maps (and theyre actually new not just old copies from the original men of war) and what Ive tried so far theyre nice as well. Hoping to see more variety on the bigger 6v6 and 8v8 maps.
3)
No gamespy. Yeah no longer must we suffer from gamespy forgetting our cd keys etc.

....More to come....

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI was in the main, interested in pre 20th Century warfare and played games accordingly.  Having become very disillusioned with a well known companies latest RTS game which I had been waiting for...for many years, I went out looking for a replacement just to keep me occupied until they got their act together and put it right.  Looking through my old games I resurrected MOWAS1, played a few games and really enjoyed myself.  Then noticed that MOWAS2 was being released in Beta during March 2014, read the blurb and signed up and duly paid my monies for the Deluxe edition...  Since then I have never looked back, I have loved every bit of the 140 odd hours played (that equates to less than £0.15p per hour), and it hasnt even been officially released yet.  Sure there are glitches (still Early Access when writing this post), but they will be resolved. the single play and Co-op has been envigorating and have made many new friends to wile away the hours with.  I highly recommend this game to anyone from a single play and Co-op play perspective (Not really played enough Multiplay to comment).  Bye-the-way, I havent even looked back to see if the ancients RTS game I waited for, has improved......

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you havent played any of the Men of War games, and I would only really recommend Men of War, Men of War Assault Squad and to some extent Men of War Red Tide. Then do so now! Men of War is the successor to Soldiers Heroes of WW2 and Faces of War. In many respects the game remained unchanged for many years and then DMS took the reigns with the Assault Squad frnachise. Assault Squad largely focusses on MP and whilst there are Single Player skirmish, these again are recommended to be played in Co Op. There is no SP campaign like the MoW or Red Tide games.

So what about Assault Squad 2? Its in beta atm and so there are performance issues and bugs as to be expected. The major ground work on AS2 is the engine improvements, graphic updates, new models for many vehicles and tanks and lots of new MP maps and SP missions/skirmish.

The gameplay is largely the same as AS. The UI has more detailed information now. The UI does look a little bit cluttered for my liking but I am sure a mod will simplify this and it is still in beta so may change for release.

AS2, no more Gamespy! yea! Easier installation and file sharing of mods. In game voice chat. Better options in MP. Having played the beta the SP Skirmish is similar to AS, but there arent waves of enemy attacks. It feels more structured and you get extra resources dependent on your actions. In all the SP side and Co OP looks promising and is a bit more creative than the skirmishes in AS. MP the new maps look and play well. Performance is impacting MP atm, but patches are being released every few days.

Overall not a huge amount different to AS, although the improvements to the engine have upgraded to Multi Core CPU support and therefore the graphics are really looking top notch. The tank models are outstanding. New MP and SP maps should keep us MoW players happy for some time. The new UI gives more information including unit kills per unit.

A complex game which just keeps getting better and better. If you compare AS2 to MoW MP the difference is huge. I wouldnt go back, however the SP portion of MoW is more captivating.

reviewText:
I have over 600 hours on AS1.

I have to say, I am majorly disappointed in this game. Like everyone else is saying, this feels like a worse version of AS1. The grenade timer feels very nooby and unnecessary. The performance is even worse, and the game has dissolved into 3+ assault squads at the beginning of every game. Just watch the good players play and you'll see this. It gets boring and repetitive. Whoever gets the lucky grenade pretty much wins the whole game, as it is near-impossible to recover from a beginning loss. AS1 was better because you could call in vehicles earlier to stop yourself from being swarmed and mgs were more effective in holding off waves.  Wah Wah! I let people gain an advantage over me early on and I don't deserve to be punished with people dug in on a point! DMS make it so I can charge head on into MGs and people in cover and actually win.



The balancing also needs some work even after 6 months of continuous analysis by the best players on the game.

I would go back to AS1 immediately if gamespy wasn't down.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a veteran of 450+ hours on Men of War: Assault Squad and a closed beta tester of this game, I feel inclined to give a review.

Men of War Assault Squad 2 is a both a step forward that just has a little way to go before it is a success. It features some fantastic new features, namely the UI, steam support, and graphical enhancements. New missions give the single player more life than the challenging, yet monotonous skirmishes of its predecessor. The new vehicle textures are spectacular, including unique camoflage based on environment. Although the infantry textures are somewhat outdated, they don't detract from the game, same with the foliage and shaders.

Once again, a relatively steep learning curve is displayed, requiring refined skills that can only be achieved through dedicated online play. You CANNOT just jump in and expect to win like other RTS games. You have to be patient and learn from your mistakes. Furthermore, you must dedicate yourself to learning the wider variety of control features the game displays, including the glorious direct control mode that allows for the most epic tank maneuvers you'll experience within the genre, the intuitive unit equiping system that allows you to loot and recover lost weapons and ammo, and finally the vehicle damage/penetration/component damage system, repairing vehicles based on where they were hit. Each of these features are what seperate the Men of War games from the rest of the genre, and mastering them is the key to success in multiplayer and getting over that curve.

The only qualm I have so far with the game is the multiplayer connection glitches. 1 in every 2 games I have played so far have poor framerates, disconnects, or straight up crashes. This makes multiplayer somewhat unplayable for me right now, whereas Assault Squad 1 had very few online issues. I'm confident, however, that the developers will have the multiplayer optimized by the full release, and as I understand, very few other players have had these issues.

Overall, I definatly reccommend this game to both veterans of the series and new players who want a massive tactical challenge. So long as you don't give up, this series can become one of the most rewarding and intuitive experiences you'll ever find.

PS: To those who would compare this to Company of Heroes, they are different on fundamental levels. COH is an arcade style fast paced base builder with nowhere near as much thought to detail and realism on the level that MOW displays, but is a very fun game for what it is. Don't compare them, just enjoy them both based on what you find to be most satifying.

If you have played Men of War assualt squad then this will be a very familure game. date: halftracks 5tons and duce-n-a-halfs this game brings a fast as well as very realistic feel to World War instead of a cookie cutter cut and paste game where everyone is equal. You may not experiance the many small (or large) issues that the allies and axis had in WW2 with things breaking on tanks (from notmal use) but it is still a great game."

reviewText: This game brings the realistic tactical battlefield experience to players with updated graphics as compared to its predecessors like Sudden Strike and Blitzkreig series. One of the greatest things about this game is that the scale of battle is between COH series and wargame series; The unit count is bigger than COH which give the better feel of coordinating large armies while, being smaller than Wargame, the units are not too tiny or represented by NATO conventions most of the time. Do not be fooled by other reviewers saying the mission are a mundane tasks of assault and defense, the map design is different for each mission which brings the difference in experience. (urban assault, farmland stomp or heavily fortified HQ, etc)\n\nI feel the main focus of the game is on tank battles which are the most fun and memorable in WWII era games. The tanks details and mechanics are well modelled. There are things like modular damage (track and turret damage, crew injury), selectable ammunitions (HE, AP, etc) which bring the realism in these battles. If you like to play plastic green soldiers when you were a kid, this is highly recommended for you!

reviewText:
ive been a fan since before early release. ive supported the Devs during the difficult times dealing with conversion from Gamespy to Steam and the troubles fixing problems that turned out to not be their fault.
I am a solo gamer who occasionaly enjoys playing coop mod missions not contained in vanilla game.. as an engine for such mods, i am getting much more than my moneys worth. hundreds of hours avail of good, fun gaming.
However. this game was focused on and sold as a Multiplay game with Match Making w ranks and ladders etc.
Sadly, despite all the efforts so far by the Devs, the game is a miserable problem/headache for the MP and MM communities.  not being one of them i can not go into details on just what all is wrong.  But i know many who do and they are .... frustrated and ... unhappy in increasing numbers.
Do I reccomend this game?  as I said, I am getting  hundreds of hours of gaming fun and cannot really dis the game or the Devs, I have no prob dealing with the coop rules.
So, if you like solo mod missions, Workshop is loaded with awesome ones I reccomend buying it.
IF  you are seeking that 8v8 monster battle lag free etc etc  or  you want to climb the ladder in Match Making, the game so far is still a work in progress with the public not knowing when it will be playable as marketed.
the DLC was NOT thought out well. hmm ok so its a taste of whats to come"  as in its a small sample of bigger work that will NOT be charged extra for once its ready.  it just seems backwards to me.  you want me to pay for a preview (some might say demo at this point) but youll give me the full blown implemintation for free....
OVERALL
recommended: i did decide to change my review rating.  I have had more than my moneys worth already. im also sure that eventually
hoursPlayed: the Devs will figure out and fix whats wrong and the MP community will get the game they all want.. or at least most of them since its impossible to make everyone happy."
