reviewText:
Wow this game is awesome.
Well first of all I would say the game is a rts game but where you do not have to rush" from a-b.
You can often take your time to scout and plan your attack or defence.

What I like about the game is the amount of detail.
For example you can drive a tank and your self shoot the enemy.
One of the really cool things about the game is that every vehicle are different.. For example it does matter where and how you shoot the enemy tank.
Another thing i like is that your troops can pickup different weapons if the for example run out of ammunition. Yes you can even use the enemys AT gruns and even tanks if you are lucky enough that the crew bail out
date:
then you can sometimes repair it and use it.
Defensive possitions and the world in general also offer various advantages or disadantages.

In general I like the game and it is pretty cool.
I have so far only completed the introduction mission 1 and it took 1 hour 45 minutes. I did not count the amount of missions but I would say 30+ so there are many houres of combat if you like to just play against the computer.. If you like there is also multiplayer but I did not yet try this.

Edit..:  If you want to play against "bots" in your own multiplayer skirmish mode
recommended: then bots AI are not included as standard in the game ( dooh )  But when buying "airborn" then the "bots AI" computer player will be unlocked... Just thought I mention this.\n\nI hope the future of the series might evolve into a game with a virtuel 2d map where we can move troops arround on a strategic map
hoursPlayed: and then fight the entire war in a kind of virtual campaign taking place in zones that look like european contrys.. .. Well the campaign system should work like in "wargame dragon". For examle if you move an infantry unit to "denmark" and the enemy move inf+light tanks then you as the player have to fight that battle with only infantry avaliable... The amount of killed units should after the battle be updated on the campaign map and once example the enemys infantry battalion is destroyed then it should be dead for the rest of the war.... however taking various key points on the campaign map should allow the player to get a fre units of reinforsment during the campaign
voteText: and the enemy vise vesa... Well that would be pretty cool to play the game like that i think. Who know maybe we could get airplanes and ships also."

reviewText:
I love this game, I really ♥♥♥♥ing do.
But Jesus.
♥♥♥♥ing.
Christ.
This AI is some of the worst I've seen in a long ♥♥♥♥ing time. Apparently my infantry, as trained as any other, will get murdered will spread out, shifting the suppression so it has to cover multiple people, DOESN'T WORK for some reason. Boy, I'm glad somebody can stack a bunch of units that are getting shot at by a tank still fire back 5x more than my infantry that is just going against a squad of infantry that's bunched up while they're spread out. Seems pretty cool. Snap shot shooting is even WORSE, I haven't seen my AI do it yet, but I've seen one snipe one my units over a ♥♥♥♥ing river, through some grass just to kill him in time before he finally (after three years) starts to throguh a frag grenade. I've also seen tanks that normally can't penetrate any part of a tank not give a ♥♥♥♥ and still kill it somehow (this is all frontal, the turrent had enough armor as well to repel it) . My infantry by the way in the SAME GAME(S) THAT IT HAPPENED IN, COULDN'T kill people out in the open. Looks like my well trained German soldiers with Kar 98s, an MG42 and some MP40s are actually ♥♥♥♥ing monkeys. However, when the sandbags somehow ♥♥♥♥ing finished all my infantry got ♥♥♥♥ing demolished when they were in cover.
The game is underful, but the AI in PvP is ♥♥♥♥ing KILLING ME, I haven't seen much of a problem with Skirmish AI but as SOON AS I SWITCH TO PVP Hooollllyyy shiiittt. From what I can see I would recommend this game, but, you may notice some of the AI problems like I have. I like this game I really do, but, I don't like being punched in the face for trying to play against other people. If you can get by these annoyances this game is actually really amazing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I used to play Company of Heroes 1 and 2. I used to enjoy doing so. But then one day I discovered Men of War Assault squad. A game that balances realism and gameplay. Infantry out in the open will die in two seconds under mg fire. Flamethrowers kill whoever they shoot at. Flanking, retreating, feinting. This game is far more tactical and strategic than Company of heroes can ever hope to be. Armored battles are both thrilling and nerve racking. A single shell in the right place can end a one on one armor battle. Medium tanks have the same armor stats as their in real life counterparts. Medium tanks will bounce almost every shell off their strong upper glacis armor, but lower glacis is weak like irl. Its outstanding. I am in love with this series and hope to see its player base grow. I am sad that games with far more limited mechanics than this are seen as outstanding, I used to be such a person my self.

Please try this game. It is so beautiful. Gameplay over graphics.

reviewText:
Wow this game is awesome.
Well first of all I would say the game is a rts game but where you do not have to rush" from a-b.
You can often take your time to scout and plan your attack or defence.

What I like about the game is the amount of detail.
For example you can drive a tank and your self shoot the enemy.
One of the really cool things about the game is that every vehicle are different.. For example it does matter where and how you shoot the enemy tank.
Another thing i like is that your troops can pickup different weapons if the for example run out of ammunition. Yes you can even use the enemys AT gruns and even tanks if you are lucky enough that the crew bail out
date:
then you can sometimes repair it and use it.
Defensive possitions and the world in general also offer various advantages or disadantages.

In general I like the game and it is pretty cool.
I have so far only completed the introduction mission 1 and it took 1 hour 45 minutes. I did not count the amount of missions but I would say 30+ so there are many houres of combat if you like to just play against the computer.. If you like there is also multiplayer but I did not yet try this.

Edit..:  If you want to play against "bots" in your own multiplayer skirmish mode
recommended: then bots AI are not included as standard in the game ( dooh )  But when buying "airborn" then the "bots AI" computer player will be unlocked... Just thought I mention this.\n\nI hope the future of the series might evolve into a game with a virtuel 2d map where we can move troops arround on a strategic map
hoursPlayed: and then fight the entire war in a kind of virtual campaign taking place in zones that look like european contrys.. .. Well the campaign system should work like in "wargame dragon". For examle if you move an infantry unit to "denmark" and the enemy move inf+light tanks then you as the player have to fight that battle with only infantry avaliable... The amount of killed units should after the battle be updated on the campaign map and once example the enemys infantry battalion is destroyed then it should be dead for the rest of the war.... however taking various key points on the campaign map should allow the player to get a fre units of reinforsment during the campaign
voteText: and the enemy vise vesa... Well that would be pretty cool to play the game like that i think. Who know maybe we could get airplanes and ships also."

reviewText: 10/10 One of the best RTS games I've ever played, up there with battles in Rome Total War. Although this game requires a learning curve, once you learn it, it can be a hell of a lot of fun. The amount of units give you a wide variety of ways to deal with the enemy, this goes for both the campaign and the multiplayer. However this game does have its bugs and glitches and does require pretty good internet and decent PC/Laptop to run, the awesome clutch moments and hilarious moments you can have completely outwiegh all of that. The mods are alos really good, making realism even better although a little bit harder, I suggest you rack up a few hours of the vanilla game before taking mods on because they really change gameplay. If you love the World War 2 time period and love RTS games, this should be your dream to play, however if you play War Thunder, a few things are different so keep that in mind. reviewText:
This is the most frustrating game I have ever played, but somehow I keep coming back for more. I love playing RTS games, and this one is on top of my list.  Every unit is important during the game play.  Each one gets their own inventory, with access other units as well.  While they start with limited ammo, you can search the dead for more.

Like any game, it has it's down falls.  The biggest peeve I have is with enemy units being able to see mine across the map, while I can't see them.  The more I play this, the more the AI for each unit seems to get dumber.  I had one unit run circles around an enemy as I clicked for it to attack, literally doing circles like a dog around your legs.  It has a lot of little things that make you scream at the game because it's so frustrating.  But it's so addicting, I keep going back for more.

Micro managing is crucial with this game, making it very difficult to master.  The enemy AI (Easy, Normal, Hard, Heroic) are all challenging, almost impossible to play without other friends.  Which is one amazing aspect because you can play every mission with up to 7 other players LAN or internet.  Don't expect to beat a good mission in a short amount of time this game takes lots of time.

I don't like the personal leveling for this game.  You have to beat an entire mission to get an exp., this counts for first person controlling of a unit as well.  There could be an actual storyline for each campaign, not just the same ten missions for each country.

Every unit is extraordinary. The detail, the movements, even the gunfire immerses you.  The sounds and feels of the game are amazing.

This game still has quite a few bugs, as I cannot load a saved game right from the main menu.  I once had an invincible enemy unit enter the field, an every unit I had could not take it out. So I had to restart the mission, very frustrating since it was the largest tank at the end of the mission.  Also many times main mission objectives don't activate, making you restart the mission.

THE UNIT AI IS HORRENDOUS!! They are always standing up by themselves, which in turn is a death sentence in this game.  Medics do not do anything but create another target for the enemy, same with units that have AT grenades/ rockets.
I wish there was tutorial missions to get you into the flow of the combat, that way you can use every aspect of the game.

I've downloaded some mods, and they bring this game to a whole new level.  The talent some of these people have makes you think they work for the developers.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This was a total nostalgia trip for me as it is just like an indirect sequel to Soldiers: Heroes of World War 2 (one of the most memorable games I've played as a kid). It's so amazing how much it has improved in terms of AI and graphics in the game. (Even though the AI is still flawed). Sucks that I didn't watch it grow with the previous games over the years... :(

I really like the workshop support for this game as gamers like us can put in and share our own missions, mods in the game (and there a really some talented ones at that). The 'direct control' function in the game sure is unique and really helpful in some situations, although I hear some people complaining about the 3rd person missions DLC. Hey, what's wrong with devs trying new things? The game isn't that strong storywise and all the factions have practically the same missions but on different maps, so singleplayer is pretty bland overall. However, being able to play them cooperatively with a buddy pretty much makes up for it. Haven't really tried multiplayer yet and I'll give it a go someday. Till then, co-op for days!

Will recommend this game for WWII lovers as well as RTS lovers. It's really unique in my opinion. Give it a go!

9/10 will get my Tiger detracked again

reviewText:
A extremely realistic WWII-RTS game.this game has a lot of depth,with very detailed stealth and armor penetration mechanics.
everything is important in this game:is your infantry supplied with enough ammunition,grenades and other supplies?are your vehicles fueled up?do you need to repair tacks or a drive wheel?all those are important small bits that can make the difference in a fight.set up ambushes to penalize cocky players by destroying their heavy tanks with a single rocket or burn them out of the foilage with flamethrowers to clear the path for your armor.

a special thanks to the active support of the developer team.if you have a question about the game you can be sure to get an  answer from the devs themselves in the discussion threads.

i would say singleplayer is my biggest negative point.while the stealth and defense missions are fun the attack missons are pretty unplayable due to the massive spam of enemy counterattacks.its not fun being greeted by panzers when you only have AT rifles.

reviewText:
I love this game would be an understatement, especially once you add the Sir Henkle mod.

A hardcore RTS where every soldier has his own inventory, and tough but fair combat on hard mode.

The only this that bothers me is when you play online and you order a squad then your friend gets half the forces when he has less, which don't get me wrong kinda makes sense, but when I order a unit I need it in full squad not just 1/4th of the squad. It's fixable by having your friend gift the units back to you but it should be an option not enforced by default.

At the time of writing this I have played 101.8 hours and loved every second of it.

reviewText:
9/10, best strategy game released in years. easily equals eugen's wargame for strategic depth and complexity.


it's micro intensive, but very satisfying. the factions are diverse and there are many, many maps. to boot, it's half the price of a normal game with at least 10x the content. if you're an RTS fan, you won't be disappointed; if you're new, stick with it: the learning cliff is tall, sure. but the summit is worth the climb.

reviewText:
What im about to say is difficult for me to articulate without sounding like a noob who cant play or someone who's computer is a potatoe. I am a master league sc2 player and my pc has a radeon 6850, just for clarification. I have also tested this on a friends pc  and everything is the same.

I have noticed that if you issue commands very quickly they do not register and its as if you never issued them. e.g. If you select 5 groups of men and move them all by rapidly pressing the correct # keys then clicking with your mouse, often only the first group or two will have received the command despite you pressing each group key then clicking. This also happens when trying to rapidly click and drag over units and grouping them, jumping between several vehicles to change ammo, telling multiple artillery to fire on ground, telling a squad to throw several gernades, ect.
This will happen in offline skirmish with graphics as low as they go.

This just seems to be how the game is programmed, its like the game can only process APMs so fast and if you go beyond that it doesn't work. I suppose this could be a hardware problem on my and my friends end, perhaps our Cpus are too weak or something like that. But i dont know, in sc2/planetary annihilation i can issue commands as fast as my body will let me, i can rapidly hit group keys and issue move orders and everyone of those commands works and they all start moving. In Sc2 i can click and drag and make up 5 groups in about 2 seconds, in MOWAS2 this is just impossible.

I asked my friend if he noticed this and he said he didn't, i went over to his home and reproduced it, clearly noobs cannot see this problem; you have to be able to micro. I am an armchair historian and i enjoy this game because of that and also i suspect eveyone has this APM cap to deal with so its not like anyone has an unfair edge But still if you are a high ranked RTS player and you know how to micro, sometimes this game will make you want to stick a fork in your eye.

Early Access Review

reviewText:
TL;DR
If you're into WW2 RTS games, Men of War: Assault Squad 2 is probably worth full price. Plenty of content, a fairly active multiplayer scene, an abundance of mods, and rock-solid mechanics. There are some issues - mainly engine and online stability issues - but they don't necessarily ruin the game. DLC isn't spectacular, but Airborne is worth the buy. MOW:AS2 is definitely worth the price, especially if it is on sale.

Graphics & Sound
Functional. Not much to write home about but the game looks pretty and it doesn't eat your framerate. Sounds aren't terribly impressive but they work well enough. Voice acting is iffy, with a lot of it being recycled from previous MOW games.

Core Gameplay
Incredibly fun. MOW:AS2 adds a lot of nice additions to Men of War's already awesome gameplay. Although it can be micro-heavy, infantry combat is enjoyable and the inventory system gives the players much more freedom than similar WW2 RTS games. Vehicle combat is also a lot of fun, thanks to the ability to directly control your vehicles. AS2 also adds plenty of helpful UI elements and mechanics that just build on the classic MOW gameplay.

Single-Player
Not brilliant, but not bad. There isn't a campaign to speak of - just a large number of individual skirmish missions. They all tend to be very similar as well, which can be problematic if you get bored by samey missions. Despite the similarities, the skirmishes themselves can be pretty enjoyable, especially the defensive skirmish missions. However, stealth missions are flat-out terrible, in my opinion, because of the game's AI. Skip them.

Multi-Player
Pretty good. Balance-wise, the game isn't brilliant. At least, it doesn't beat Company of Heroes in terms of balance. Still, Germany vs. USA games and Soviet vs. Germany games are well balanced, and thus quite popular online. However, the matches themselves are a lot less predictable, since there is high capacity for shenanigans thanks to the gameplay mechanics. This can be good or bad, depending on your play style. Still, the competitive multiplayer is enjoyable.

Also worth noting is the ability to play the single-player skirmish missions cooperatively. If you have a friend or two that like WW2 RTS, playing the coop skirmish missions on a higher difficulty can make for a really good time. You can also play modded skirmish missions cooperatively, so there is actually a wide array of coop content.

As of me writing this review, the game's online has a number of stability issues, primarily the Out of Sync" issue
date: which can disconnect a player and ruin the flow of the game. The devs have said that they are working on it
hoursPlayed:
especially since it is a fairly common problem.

Modding
Men of War games have had good modding scenes for quite some time. AS2 is no exception. In fact
voteText: I would say it has one of the best modding scenes out of the entire franchise. There's a lot of total conversion mods that can completely change the game
helpfulPercent:
adding a lot of replayability. There are also tons of custom skirmish missions and multiplayer maps. The modding scene is active and adds a lot to the game.

DLC
The DLC for this game is not particularly great. For starters
votesHelpful: the Deluxe Edition is a complete ripoff. The XP boost is pointless
votesTotal: since a lot of servers play with unlocked units
votesFunny: and unless you REALLY want that fancy nametag

reviewText: Really fun game, when it works. Atrocious amounts of glitches and bugs. Be prepared to fight the unresponsive soldiers, inability to resupply some units, your commands not being obeyed, and soldiers being stuck on their way to designated position, i.e. unable to go around obstacles, and stepping in place. AI seems infinetely stupid, and a bit overpowered, i.e. constant suppply of them is a bit overdone. Micromanagement is ridiculous, i.e. you need to re-supply all squads under fire,  but supply units are first to be fired upon. Snipers are useless, as they can't see any further than other units, and can't shoot very quickly, so they will do a kill every now and then, and that's all. Waves of incoming units are ridiculous, as there's no time to re-supply properly, or actually fight the resupply system, as soldiers just don't want to re-supply in most cases. There's no control over how and when vehicles like tanks fire from their main gun and when from the MG.\nDon't get me wrong, it's really nice game, but ridden with bugs. Btw... when you get angry and frustrated due to such issues, ALT-F4 doesn't work.

This game doesnt get the attention it deserves. I am a terrible strategy player, but was able to scrape by the AI and a few players. Now, this game is very realistic, as vehicles and infantry have excellent hitpoints, and MP is a good mechanic. MOW: AS 2 does not have a unit cap, which, in my opinion, is pivitol in PC strategy games, as it makes the game feel better and gives a sense of freedom.

The MP system is a masterfully good way to limit the warfare, and sorta attaches you to what units you have.MP recharges, and judges how many units you can deploy.  There is a mechanic where you can take over a unit directly, and is HORRID when using for infantry. The controls are clunkly, its impossible to aim, and you can't take cover in direct control mode. But vehicle direct control is very good. The controls are nice and smooth, though i remember overshooting my movement a little bit too much.

Maps are limited in quantity, but downloading them from the workshop is a must. I personally reccomend Sir Hinkels missions, as they are welll balanced for both sides, and D-Day was AMAZING. Except for the script explosions, those killed my entire horde of american infantry as i was rushing them to the left.

The factions have their own strengths, and i mostly just played as the Americans, Germany and Russia. The Ruskies have the ability to spam units, to make up for their ♥♥♥♥♥♥ quality. The Americans are in the middle for me, and Germany had the best units, in my opinion. NOTE: There are many more factions. Overall, a 6/10.
voteText: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText: If you are a fan of the Men of War series you will love Assault Squad 2. There is not a MAJOR difference from the first MoW:AS. There are various bugs and issues that have been fixed from the original. Also if you enjoy playing MoW online I recommend buying this game. Since this is currently the newest and most polished MoW there are more players to play with on AS2.\n\nIf you are new to this series but enjoy ww2 RTS games I highly recommend this game. It is in between some of the more hardcore games such as Theatre of War and the more arcade casual Company of Heroes series. I feel it is the perfect balance of realism and fun. It has historically acurate units and armor penetration values. For added realism there are many mods that can enhance this aspect of the game. For players new to the series it will not seem as user friendly in the way Company of Heroes is. I have spent hours playing this series and still go back for more. I have yet to be bored with this game. I would personally give this game an 8/10.

reviewText:
Single player campaign seems to be simillar for all the different factions (at least for the first mission).

I only bought this game for the multiplayer and I can report there wasn't much of an experience there. The fps somehow is linked to the other players internet connection and results in getting very low fps (13ish) sometimes.
The main problem I have is that there simply isn't much people playing mp. There was only one non-passworded room and it was running a mod that I didn't have downloaded. When I joined a different game to play I got kicked by the host because I'm a noob. I tried making my own room and no wanted to play me after 5 minutes of waiting.
Even in the one 1v1 game I did get to play, there was visible lag on the units at times.
Some of the graphics and animations in the game seem to be low quailty.

I think there is a lot more value in the campaign of company of heroes 1 compared to this game.
voteText: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I recommend this to all fans of the MoW series and players let down by other RTS games (looking at you CoH2).

The good:
- superb realism and great combat mechanics
- superb physics and terrain destruction
- many units for each faction and many maps
- multiplayer and matchmaking (it was difficult to play good multiplayer in the previous games of the series and this one finally fixed that)
- difficult (in a good way - make sure you learn all the game's systems before playing competitive multi)

The bad:
- very similar to Assault Squad 1, even some single player maps are recycled (may be a + for some players)
- single player campaing may be seen as too disconnected, too little story (but may be treated as a good training for multi)
- difficult (casual players may feel frustrated if they are not willing to learn the game)

reviewText: Bought this DLC for the AI, been waiting forever for AI for this game! and to support the DEVS and might i say they did not dissapoint! The added on AI is amazing and fun! they play strictly with assault zones so far and even with the Modded Map packs that i have downloaded! There are some stuff the AI does pretty stupidly from time to time like charging in artillary peices as tanks, or using tanks as infantry to cap assault points. But what AI doesnt have problems? can always be patched up! although any difficultly besides heroic can be pretty easy. heroic is just right for me i feel since theres a lot of stuff to deal with and counter! perfect for practicing with! I havent tried the airborne missions though but knowing their singleplayer tendencies its most likely great! Id say if your tired of facing complaining humans in the MP or being kicked all the time for stupid reasons BUY THIS DLC!! its worth every penny! and its fun facing the AI when it doesnt mess up! always fun to comp stomp or if your at work to kill a little time! Great job Devs hats off to ya! keep up the great work!

reviewText:
Loads of fun, tactical strategy game mixed with a slight RPG element in which you can equip your guys with ammo, helms and bullets. There are micromanagement aspects to it that help you take control of an individual unit.

This game is especially fun with friends (what game isn't?). Have your friend (or yourself) call out strats, while you can micromanage your units. Then dish out an insane amount of hurt with whatever shared resource funding is allotted to your team.

My most favorite (albeit annoyingly stereotypical) aspect of this game is its call in units, specifically, the Soviet's For the Motherland!" ability.

Would Order No. 227 the fascists while blaring the soviet anthem or worker's marseillaise anyday of the week."

reviewText:
This game is definitely underrated and highly enjoyable to even the most non rts type players once you work out the kinks.
Though not without issues, this game is a master piece.

Gameplay- 10/10
Without a doubt, this game caters to a more precise crowd of people. The level of control over your units alone is enough to salivate the most hardcore of fans in the RTS genre.
The actual battles themselves? Pure unadulturated goodness. Your troops actually matter. Their positions actually matter. The different types of units actually matter. In other games things like AA guns and some MG placements just get killed early and barely make any difference in the fight. COH2 being one such example. However in this game, each and every unit can have a massive affect on the battle. Very unique playstyles can be done in this game.

Content - 10/10
The fact that it has 5 fully fleshed out factions is amazing in itself. Other such games in this genre could learn from this. The amount of units within these factions is awesome as well. Yeah some of them are copy and paste but it definitely is enjoyable to be to have diversity.

Graphics -6/10
Somewhat lacking given the year this came out in. Though I understand it's difficult to do RTS games with amazing graphics and still have everything running correctly. Still, aesthetically pleasing for the most part.

Story - 5/10
Not played too much of the story. But pretty similar to other such games in this genre. Typical WW2 scenarios and plot driven kill the enemy type scenarios.

Cinematics - 2/10
One of the only things I find annoying about this game is the little cut scenes in some of the missions, especially during a skirmish when playing with a friend and you lose track of your units when it comes on.

Music - 3/10
The music gets extremely repetitive.

Controls - 9/10
The controls takes a lot of getting used to if you want to be good. However, they are there for a purpose and once you figure it all out you are a master of the battlefield.

Multiplayer - 9/10
One of my only cons about this game is that during the Multiplayer if someone has a terrible connection or a not so good graphics card, everyone tends to suffer from lag. I've yet to play a game where the MP was extremely stable and there wasn't some weird frame skipping when you moved players.  Other than that, it's addicting. You willl never feel so satisfied as you do when you win multiplayer matches. It is absolutely addicting. It's been a long time since a game has made me feel like this.


Overall, this game is absolutely worth the price, especially on sale!
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful

The fact that it has 5 fully fleshed out factions is amazing in itself. Other such games in this genre could learn from this. The amount of units within these factions is awesome as well. Yeah some of them are copy and paste but it definitely is enjoyable to be to have diversity.

Graphics -6/10
Somewhat lacking given the year this came out in. Though I understand it's difficult to do RTS games with amazing graphics and still have everything running correctly. Still, aesthetically pleasing for the most part.

Story - 5/10
Not played too much of the story. But pretty similar to other such games in this genre. Typical WW2 scenarios and plot driven kill the enemy type scenarios.

Cinematics - 2/10
One of the only things I find annoying about this game is the little cut scenes in some of the missions, especially during a skirmish when playing with a friend and you lose track of your units when it comes on.

Music - 3/10
The music gets extremely repetitive.

Controls - 9/10
The controls takes a lot of getting used to if you want to be good. However, they are there for a purpose and once you figure it all out you are a master of the battlefield.

Multiplayer - 9/10
One of my only cons about this game is that during the Multiplayer if someone has a terrible connection or a not so good graphics card, everyone tends to suffer from lag. I've yet to play a game where the MP was extremely stable and there wasn't some weird frame skipping when you moved players.  Other than that, it's addicting. You willl never feel so satisfied as you do when you win multiplayer matches. It is absolutely addicting. It's been a long time since a game has made me feel like this.


Overall, this game is absolutely worth the price, especially on sale!

reviewText:
First off, I love the mow series, the first game, assault squad, vietnam, all of them.

Alot of people say this is the exact same game as as1, and really, it is pretty much the same, but many game mechanics were changed, which is good.  They took some really important features out of this game, but they added good mod support, to correct these problems.  I like this game, but it is really similar to as1 with not enough differences, which I dont like, I really only recommend this game if you havent played as1, or are new to the series.

And with the maps, there are VERY good new maps which I absolutely adore, but in some of them, I realized there is no versatility, no game-changing things, and it gets almost robotic, for example, im USA facing Japan, the enemy player sends a kamikazi, sneaks through all of my lines, and then takes out my sherman jumbo.  Im spooked, and then reinforce my lines and everything, but within that few seconds of attempting to strengthen my lines, the enemy player attacks with elite infantry and light tanks, which I cant counter because of my jumbo gone, and I lose the game because of one kamikazi.  I just dont see that anymore in as2, atleast, not often enough, and that a major flaw in this game for me, making me at times really frustrated.

reviewText:
Bought this game expecting much the same as COH.  Have to say the detail is much greater than I had expected.  (picking up and using dropped weapons, vehicle damage is down to the panel hit, soldiers helments flying off when shot).  I do think some of the historical accuraces in terms of when certain weapons and tanks become available leave a lot to be desired in the scenarios.

Whilst this is squad oriented you can move individual soldiers, this can be a help and a hinderance.. it does become a bit to much like micro management.. i.e having to heal troops when a medic is right next to them, or having to individually supply troops with new ammo when they are all standing around the supply truck... this does leave it a little frenetic in the heat of battle.

I started the game on normal difficulty which seems REALLY difficult.. so switched to easy which seems far to easy so struggling with getting the right tempo.. artillery strikes are rediculously accurate in the scenarios.. to the point a nebellwerfer was more pinpoint accurate than an 88.....and loaded and fired more quickly it seemed.

Apart from those little gripes the scale of the maps, certain micro management (in house out specific window) and the overall game play gave it a slightly more 'real war' feel vs COH (certainly COHII) COH is still one of the best , WWII squad games available but this is up there.

It crashes ON THE F#CK|NG TITLE SCREEN if you leave it alone for too long.

reviewText:
I consider MOWAS2 to be one of the finest RTS games ever made.

1) All the MOW games are pretty similar, and all good.  There are many complaints about how MOWAS2 is the same game as MOWAS, and this is largely true, but not a reason to rate the game down.

2) If you've played Company of Heroes, then MOWAS is similar but much more realistic - more like a WW2 simulation.  This makes it a harder game harder to learn, and harder to master but ultimately makes it feel more like you are playing WW2, rather than playing a video game (as with CoH)

3) Unfortunately DMS (the devs) are a little sketchy.  For us, the gamers, this means a) the multiplayer is sometimes unreliable and dropped games, lag and connection faliures are too frequent.  It also means you get shady things like MOWAS2 being bacisly the same as MOWAS (see above), and DLC's that are rather obviously designed just to make money and have minimal content.

Overall: an outstanding game that is an absolute MUST for any WW2 RTS lover.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Super in-depth, super detailed, super good. Not only can you steal enemy vehicles and guns, you can steal those vehicles' supplies and use them yourself, and then ASSUME DIRECT CONTROL with E and turn the game into a third-person shooter. You can control the inventory of individual infantry down to their damn hats and the bullets in their gun. The environments are almost entirely destructable to a striking degree of detail, which leads to awesome moments like when the bomber you call in for an airstrike is shot down by enemy forces (Yes, you can do that too) and it crashes into a house and knocks it to pieces.\nThe only two complaints that I have about this game are that you can't commandeer everything on the field (Battleships, a German artillery piece in one or two missions, some boats, etc), and that it's far too similar to the original MOWAS - most of the missions are just ported from the older game, and there are very few engine differences - it makes buying the older game feel like a waste of money. I suppose this could stem from the fact that they're all taken from real battles that faction actually won, but I think the base game could stand to have a little more replay value. Still, though, given how much fun it is to play the missions that are there, it doesn't hurt the game much.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Men of War 2 has always been a game that generated a lot of discussions, whether is it better than Company of Heroes 2, if it is just a vague copy of previous Men of War... In my opinion Men of War 2 is at the moment one of the best WW2 RTS games. The micro unit management gives tons of possibilities to customize your army. The fact that you can arm your soldier with whatever weapon gives that gameplay flexibility, you are no longer attached to a fixed model you can create your own army.

But there's also more cool stuff! The workshop in this game is huge, there's a lot of missions that you can play solo or co-op, which is great because you will always have something new to play. However the games has a big problem that, AI.

The enemy AI in all difficulties seems to be OK, but your AI seems to be totally stupid. The number of times my soldiers got killed for throwing AT grenades at half a meter from a tank is way too high. There will be situations where you order your soldier to throw a grenade and run through enemy fire to throw a grenade or even worse. The tanks can go full ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and turn around and give the whole back side to the enemy and get instantly killed. It is definetly frustrating the AI issue but for the rest it's a great game, the most important thing is the modding community that helps updating the game with the missions and mods-

reviewText:
This game like all the other Men of War games is a complete master piece!

This game isnt to much of a change from Men of War: Assault Squad 1, but there are some small things that make it that much better.

1: Graphics are a bit better and some bug fixes (some)

2: Better units. Example: In the mission Overlord for the americans, when calling in paratroopers a squad of 5 parachutes in, instead of just one trooper, this is a major fix in my mind, logically you would send 1 trooper in at a time and sending in squads would be a more rational" amount.

3: MAJOR FIX: mulitplayer is fixed and you can play online
date: unlike the other Men of War: Assault Squad that ran off of game spy (an unused and discontinued gaming network). This makes the game so much better
hoursPlayed: for players who has friends that don't own the game
voteText: or those who don't have friends (if you don't have any
helpfulPercent: make some!)\n\n4: This isn't a fix but makes the game so much more fun

reviewText: I've had this game for a long time and even had some fun with it when I first purchased it but then I drifted back to Company of Heroes 2 as usual. On a whim I fired up MOW AS2 today and had an absolute blast with it. This is a must play for WWII and RTS enthusiasts. It's challenging. Absolute tons of micromanaging to be done here but when you start getting it and making combined arms tactics work it is thrilling. Honestly, it's a difficult game to master and I'm not there yet but if you want a challenge this is your game. The graphics on ultra settings are very very nice and the game's presentation is more realistic" if I can use that word than Company of Heroes. Performance is a little uneven which is understandable with everything that's going on. It's crazy how many moving parts there are here so a respectable processor is recommended. I have what currently is the flagship AMD APU the A10 7850k OC'ed to 4.5ghz paired with an R9 285 and 32gb of ram (design) and when there's a lot of concentrated artillery
date: infantry and vehicle movement it can run in the low 20's though I wouldn't say it makes the game unplayable. I probably should mess around with the shadows and post processing to see if I can improve that but for the most part the game runs well. Obviously your experience will vary and if you're on a laptop or older desktop then be prepared to make serious sacrifices in the graphics settings. I should probably mention that there's no proper campaign
recommended: it's more a series of disconnected battles vs. the CPU but I didn't feel the game suffered because of a lack of narrative. If you like WWII you get the context and you can fill in the blanks yourself without having a character driven story line. Well
hoursPlayed: that's it. If you're reading this at all it's because you're interested so pull the trigger. It's a great game 9/10."
voteText: August 6, 2015

reviewText: Super in-depth, super detailed, super good. Not only can you steal enemy vehicles and guns, you can steal those vehicles' supplies and use them yourself, and then ASSUME DIRECT CONTROL with E and turn the game into a third-person shooter. You can control the inventory of individual infantry down to their damn hats and the bullets in their gun. The environments are almost entirely destructable to a striking degree of detail, which leads to awesome moments like when the bomber you call in for an airstrike is shot down by enemy forces (Yes, you can do that too) and it crashes into a house and knocks it to pieces.\nThe only two complaints that I have about this game are that you can't commandeer everything on the field (Battleships, a German artillery piece in one or two missions, some boats, etc), and that it's far too similar to the original MOWAS - most of the missions are just ported from the older game, and there are very few engine differences - it makes buying the older game feel like a waste of money. I suppose this could stem from the fact that they're all taken from real battles that faction actually won, but I think the base game could stand to have a little more replay value. Still, though, given how much fun it is to play the missions that are there, it doesn't hurt the game much.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Men of War 2 has always been a game that generated a lot of discussions, whether is it better than Company of Heroes 2, if it is just a vague copy of previous Men of War... In my opinion Men of War 2 is at the moment one of the best WW2 RTS games. The micro unit management gives tons of possibilities to customize your army. The fact that you can arm your soldier with whatever weapon gives that gameplay flexibility, you are no longer attached to a fixed model you can create your own army.

But there's also more cool stuff! The workshop in this game is huge, there's a lot of missions that you can play solo or co-op, which is great because you will always have something new to play. However the games has a big problem that, AI.

The enemy AI in all difficulties seems to be OK, but your AI seems to be totally stupid. The number of times my soldiers got killed for throwing AT grenades at half a meter from a tank is way too high. There will be situations where you order your soldier to throw a grenade and run through enemy fire to throw a grenade or even worse. The tanks can go full ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and turn around and give the whole back side to the enemy and get instantly killed. It is definetly frustrating the AI issue but for the rest it's a great game, the most important thing is the modding community that helps updating the game with the missions and mods-

reviewText:
This is a very good strategy game. It is far better than Company of Heroes 2 in every way: realism, depth, unit selection... the list goes on.

However, it has a fatal flaw: It crashes.

It crashes when you get a Steam notification.
It crashes when there's an explosion that's too big.
It crashes when you alt-tab.
It crashes when you invite a friend.
It crashes sometimes when you press the Multiplayer button.
It crashes sometimes on the multiplayer loading screen, even when finished loading.
It crashes ON THE F#CK|NG TITLE SCREEN if you leave it alone for too long.

Debugging" was not in the developer's vocabulary.

(Please note that this is NOT due to a lack of RAM or hard drive space
date: I have 8GB RAM and over 100GB of free disk space
recommended: and the game never uses more than a few GB of RAM.)"

reviewText: A fan of WWII, and strategy games? Then the MOW:AS series is for you! Of course, with only 2 games in the Assualt Sqaud series, they are nontheless fun to play. Of course, its a strategy game, but you can control your units, plus, you have access to the Steam Workshop! This game has things from the P-51 to the Ju-87, to flamethrower units to your regular infantry, to the Black Prince to the Flamethrower Sherman and Super Pershing! Of course, I didn't buy this game, it was gifted to me, but does that change my opinion, no! Buy this game and give it a whirl! And DON'T forget the Fields of Honor (German Soldiers) mod!

reviewText:
I consider MOWAS2 to be one of the finest RTS games ever made.

1) All the MOW games are pretty similar, and all good.  There are many complaints about how MOWAS2 is the same game as MOWAS, and this is largely true, but not a reason to rate the game down.

2) If you've played Company of Heroes, then MOWAS is similar but much more realistic - more like a WW2 simulation.  This makes it a harder game harder to learn, and harder to master but ultimately makes it feel more like you are playing WW2, rather than playing a video game (as with CoH)

3) Unfortunately DMS (the devs) are a little sketchy.  For us, the gamers, this means a) the multiplayer is sometimes unreliable and dropped games, lag and connection faliures are too frequent.  It also means you get shady things like MOWAS2 being bacisly the same as MOWAS (see above), and DLC's that are rather obviously designed just to make money and have minimal content.

Overall: an outstanding game that is an absolute MUST for any WW2 RTS lover.

reviewText: Super in-depth, super detailed, super good. Not only can you steal enemy vehicles and guns, you can steal those vehicles' supplies and use them yourself, and then ASSUME DIRECT CONTROL with E and turn the game into a third-person shooter. You can control the inventory of individual infantry down to their damn hats and the bullets in their gun. The environments are almost entirely destructable to a striking degree of detail, which leads to awesome moments like when the bomber you call in for an airstrike is shot down by enemy forces (Yes, you can do that too) and it crashes into a house and knocks it to pieces.\nThe only two complaints that I have about this game are that you can't commandeer everything on the field (Battleships, a German artillery piece in one or two missions, some boats, etc), and that it's far too similar to the original MOWAS - most of the missions are just ported from the older game, and there are very few engine differences - it makes buying the older game feel like a waste of money. I suppose this could stem from the fact that they're all taken from real battles that faction actually won, but I think the base game could stand to have a little more replay value. Still, though, given how much fun it is to play the missions that are there, it doesn't hurt the game much.
